Posts.Content: Hey Busby - I'm so sorry to read this and hope you're getting some relief today! Your post brought back some truly gruesome memories of my RT in 2009, near the end of which I was in such pain that I was on Oxycodone and a Fentanyl patch 24 hours a day. You can guess the result. I tried everything and spent many a morning groaning on the bathroom floor. Finally my oncology nurse suggested a simple if difficult remedy: rubber gloves. It was extremely painful but it did the trick. Hope you don't have to go this route.... but it's there for you if all else fails. Good luck and keep us posted.

Posts.Title: Single Incision RALP outpatient

Posts.Content: Thanks, ASA and Djinn. I realize that I wasn't clear enough. I'm still getting the hang of this stuff... 1. My initial 12-core TRUS biopsy came up G6 in 2 cores: one each in the right and left anterior apexes. 2. A 1.5T mpMRI 6+ weeks later revealed that the right apex malignancy was part of a lesion that the pathologist measured at 1.6cm, and said "is considered PI-5" (even though my urologist, in our talk a week later, said that while PI-5 is indeed deeply suspicious of cancer, he thought it was more likely a 3-4). 3. A second targeted UroNAV biospy was indeed centered on that right apex transition zone lesion. While the TRUS found 2 positive cores of G6 out of 12 (one on each side), the UroNAV took 6 cores on the right and found only one that was G6 - presumably indicating a third core that I'm "guessing" was near the first positive core on that side but don't really know for sure. It should be noted that in his ultrasound Dr. Bahn reduced the size of the 1.6mm lesion (I hadn't been given its width before) to 9x10mm. This seems to me a significant difference (?). He also measured my PSA at 1.8, up from 1.2 last August; and that in turn down from my last PSA of 1.4 in Feb. 2015. 4. Due to the left side's lesion's ill-defined nature (my wife and I both saw it on the ultrasound; the one of the left was fuzzy vs. the more distinct one on the right), Bahn believes it "could be the index tumor", and measured its size at 8x7mm. 5. After the UroNAV my urologist had told me that he was concerned that there might be more cancer there and therefore wasn't comfortable with just watching it. He also spoke about not wanting to miss the "treatment window", which I understand from speaking with others (at my local support group and another local group) is at the very least subject to medical opinion. That of course opens up a whole world of discussion! 6. Last weekend we attended the mid-year conference of Drs. Scholz and Moyad's Prostate Cancer Research Institute meeting. Educational if a bit thick at the science end (especially for a musician/writer like me and my retired educator wife...). One of the speakers was Dr. Kirk Wojno, who heads the path dept of a big urology group in Michigan. I was able to grab him for a quick question after his presentation and asked if it had been a mistake (so to speak) for my hospital not to have sent ALL my cores to Dr. Epstein for review a month ago (including even the positive ones from both biopsies). I had anticipated his yes answer and was not disappointed. Well, that is, I WAS disappointed that only the uroNAV slides had been sent. Oh well. 7. Finally: Kaiser, where we have our coverage, refused to send out my samples for OncotypeDX. I'd heard they were notoriously tight-fisted when it came to these things, even though Medicare will pay for it. So either I cough up the $4K myself, or leave Kaiser during open enrollment in November and buy a likely quite expensive supplemental policy myself. I just turned 65 in November and must admit to not knowing too much about how all this works. I hope this clears up what for me is still a steep learning process. Really more of a maze that I'm trying to negotiate blindfolded and with my legs in a sack! Thanks to both of you, and everyone here, for your knowledge and kindness. SC

Posts.Content: Thanks again. Yes, corrected the metric error (I'm an old fashioned inches and feet guy) and thanks for pointing that out, Djin. Thanks, Duck. There is certainly an appeals process, that is, a complaint form to fill out. I was waiting until I knew more before going that route but it seems like a good idea to try. I doubt they'll budge but I'll feel better about myself. And yes, the new doctor will have all my records in the Grand Kaiser Database. I'm fine and even dandy continuing the monitoring, Djin. What I'm opposed to is being cut or blasted if I actually don't (yet) need it. While I was born and raised in Florida I no longer live there, so I doubt if Florida Blue will help me. But thanks for mentioning it, OTS. If and when I need to make a change I'll see what I can get out here in CA. Before I joined Kaiser I had Anthem Blue Cross. It became unbearably expensive, hence the switch to Kaiser, which was conveniently where my wife was being treated. I can't fault Anthem for coverage when I needed it though, viz. during my 2009 cancer. Think that whole year ended up being billed in the $250-300K range and I only paid premiums and a deductible. No clue what it's like today.

Posts.Title: Duke Bahn and yet another opinion in the near future

Posts.Content: The latest update: My Kaiser urologist (who had not yet been copied on Dr. Bahn's report and I need to find out why) considers the CDUS inferior to MRI and says that I have "biopsy proven cancer" and that the tumor size precludes surveillance. So even when he sees Bahn's findings it won't mean anything to him. Urologist vs. Radiologist My first and frankly confused reaction is the reference to tumor size. Yes, the MRI showed a lesion of 1-1.5cm (depending on whom you ask...) and 6 cores were taken. But only one was Gleason 6, which I as a layman would read that only a portion was actually cancer. I do indeed realize that there well might be more malignancy in there than was found by the cores, and even a higher Gleason grade. But does that mean that one refers to the entire lesion as a tumor? I welcome input into my misunderstanding. Adding to the mix is something I learned Monday night at our local support group. There is a Blue Shield Plan F Extra currently on offer that is very attractive in price and types of coverage. I could leave Kaiser and go with this Medicare supplement (and also then have to buy a drug plan of course), but the catch is that it's only being offered until April 15th! Not enough time to contemplate going out into the world and finding a uro, a PCP, etc., etc. It doesn't help that my wife and I are leaving the country on Saturday. There are no easy answers. Only more and more questions! Thanks for listening, guys.

Posts.Title: Duke Bahn and yet another opinion in the near future

Posts.Content: I had a color doppler ultrasound with Dr. Bahn, who confirmed my two areas of Gleason 6 and found my PSA to be 1.8, up from 1.2 last August. He wasn't concerned with the rise. My last reading before this was in 2015 and it was 1.4. Dr. Bahn copied my urologist with his report just the other day (I don't expect to hear from the latter until and unless I get in touch with him.) and recommends AS, with PSAs every 3 months and another CDUS at 6 months, and then yearly thereafter. My urologist told me in January that I would need treatment but could take up to a year to decide which. So here are two guys with very different points of view! I'm going for the tie-breaker on May 6th with a doctor I don't know but who seems interesting. He's indeed a urologist within the Kaiser system and does the whole gamut of surgery, but also bills himself as treating the whole patient and is open to "mind-body healing".... not my particular bag, but I'm remaining open to everything. Hoping for the best! I don't have a specific question here, just putting this info out in case anyone has a comment. Thanks.

Posts.Title: Duke Bahn and yet another opinion in the near future

Posts.Content: The latest update: My Kaiser urologist (who had not yet been copied on Dr. Bahn's report and I need to find out why) considers the CDUS inferior to MRI and says that I have "biopsy proven cancer" and that the tumor size precludes surveillance. So even when he sees Bahn's findings it won't mean anything to him. Urologist vs. Radiologist My first and frankly confused reaction is the reference to tumor size. Yes, the MRI showed a lesion of 1-1.5cm (depending on whom you ask...) and 6 cores were taken. But only one was Gleason 6, which I as a layman would read that only a portion was actually cancer. I do indeed realize that there well might be more malignancy in there than was found by the cores, and even a higher Gleason grade. But does that mean that one refers to the entire lesion as a tumor? I welcome input into my misunderstanding. Adding to the mix is something I learned Monday night at our local support group. There is a Blue Shield Plan F Extra currently on offer that is very attractive in price and types of coverage. I could leave Kaiser and go with this Medicare supplement (and also then have to buy a drug plan of course), but the catch is that it's only being offered until April 15th! Not enough time to contemplate going out into the world and finding a uro, a PCP, etc., etc. It doesn't help that my wife and I are leaving the country on Saturday. There are no easy answers. Only more and more questions! Thanks for listening, guys.

Posts.Title: Duke Bahn and yet another opinion in the near future

Posts.Content: I had a color doppler ultrasound with Dr. Bahn, who confirmed my two areas of Gleason 6 and found my PSA to be 1.8, up from 1.2 last August. He wasn't concerned with the rise. My last reading before this was in 2015 and it was 1.4. Dr. Bahn copied my urologist with his report just the other day (I don't expect to hear from the latter until and unless I get in touch with him.) and recommends AS, with PSAs every 3 months and another CDUS at 6 months, and then yearly thereafter. My urologist told me in January that I would need treatment but could take up to a year to decide which. So here are two guys with very different points of view! I'm going for the tie-breaker on May 6th with a doctor I don't know but who seems interesting. He's indeed a urologist within the Kaiser system and does the whole gamut of surgery, but also bills himself as treating the whole patient and is open to "mind-body healing".... not my particular bag, but I'm remaining open to everything. Hoping for the best! I don't have a specific question here, just putting this info out in case anyone has a comment. Thanks.

Posts.Title: My Experience with Rapaflo...Anxiety

Posts.Content: It seems I've caught a case of prostate cancer, lucky me. I've been down a similar road: metastatic squamous cell carcinoma (head and neck) 9 years ago at age 55, treated with a big surgery and 31 days of IMRT. NED since then and I have every reason to believe it will never trouble me again, so bullet #1 (or more accurately, cannon shell) dodged. After meeting with a RO and a second urologist (he specializes in robotic surgery) I learned that I have a Gleason score of 3+3=6, clinically T1c. All three of the MDs including my initial urologist told me that the grading system - i.e. 1 for me - was now the norm rather than the Gleason score. My most recent PSA was 1.2, in fact down a tick from 1.4 at my last check in 2015. So I gather I'm in a pretty good place under the circumstances. I'm set to have an MRI in December after the biopsy sites heal, and then - oh goodie - a second confirmatory biopsy soon after that. In advance of those tests the docs are provisionally recommending Active Surveillance. Urologist #2 (a younger guy who seems to be on top of the latest stuff) expects a good result from the MRI and thinks it extremely unlikely that the cancer has gone anywhere outside the prostate. He mentioned optional genetic testing and said it would be a large chunk out of pocket. Dunno if Medicare, which I go on in a couple of weeks, will help with that or not but I'll certainly inquire if I decide to go that route. He did tell me that of all his patients who paid for it, none received bad news. As I recall he said that perhaps 10% of men would find out that their cancer is of the more aggressive type (or words to that effect, can't remember exactly). I'd love to get members' opinions as well as any suggestions for questions I should ask or other tests I might explore. I'm in my first week of gathering knowledge - have a couple of books on the subject, one recommended by the urologist called "Surviving Prostate Cancer" by Dr. Patrick Walsh. Also per his advice I've ordered pomegranate extract, Guanabana and Moringa. My dear friends at Amazon dot com should be showing up any minute with those. Thanks, guys. SC

Posts.Title: Hello from a new member

Posts.Content: Well, all I can say is thank you, guys. You're the best. You've really educated me in just a few short posts. Guess I had the blinkers on to some degree - maybe figuring that I've already done this dance once, so what... again? Well, yes, again. I'm with Kaiser here in Southern California and apparently every biopsy is reviewed by two different pathologists. Neither is Dr. Epstein of course, but I have confidence that a pair is better than one, and the docs I've been treated with there over the past few years have all impressed me with their competence. I'll continue to read and ask questions. Funny story about MOMA. When I was last there about 5 years ago my wife and I happened into a room with a number of Dalis and whatnot. A father entered kind of pushing his about 10 or 11 year-old son. I assumed he was dragging the kid to see the art whether he wanted it or not. They stopped in front of a painting (likely the iconic Persistence of Memory) and I could see the kid was unhappy to be there. I waited for the whining, but instead he said "Oh, dad. You know I hate surrealism!" Only in New York.

Posts.Title: Results of my fusion MRI... and confusion!

Posts.Content: Djinn - thanks for your usual lightning-quick reply. To the best of my knowledge they took...hmm... I think it was 12 cores the first time, of which 2 were positive at 5% and 15% on the right and left respectively The fusion biopsy took 6 more, of which 1 was positive at 10%. Which I interpret to mean that the other 5 (and these were all targeted from that 1.5 cm mass) were not positive. That's an interesting comment "too much of a tumor burden", and I guess that's what my uro is thinking too. At any event I have a phone convo scheduled with him in a week. I also joined a local support group that meets next Monday, so maybe someone will have more insight for me there too - to add to yours and anyone else who might chime in on this post! Posts.Content: Well, all I can say is thank you, guys. You're the best. You've really educated me in just a few short posts. Guess I had the blinkers on to some degree - maybe figuring that I've already done this dance once, so what... again? Well, yes, again. I'm with Kaiser here in Southern California and apparently every biopsy is reviewed by two different pathologists. Neither is Dr. Epstein of course, but I have confidence that a pair is better than one, and the docs I've been treated with there over the past few years have all impressed me with their competence. I'll continue to read and ask questions. Funny story about MOMA. When I was last there about 5 years ago my wife and I happened into a room with a number of Dalis and whatnot. A father entered kind of pushing his about 10 or 11 year-old son. I assumed he was dragging the kid to see the art whether he wanted it or not. They stopped in front of a painting (likely the iconic Persistence of Memory) and I could see the kid was unhappy to be there. I waited for the whining, but instead he said "Oh, dad. You know I hate surrealism!" Only in New York.

Posts.Title: Results of my fusion MRI... and confusion!

Posts.Content: It seems I've caught a case of prostate cancer, lucky me. I've been down a similar road: metastatic squamous cell carcinoma (head and neck) 9 years ago at age 55, treated with a big surgery and 31 days of IMRT. NED since then and I have every reason to believe it will never trouble me again, so bullet #1 (or more accurately, cannon shell) dodged. After meeting with a RO and a second urologist (he specializes in robotic surgery) I learned that I have a Gleason score of 3+3=6, clinically T1c. All three of the MDs including my initial urologist told me that the grading system - i.e. 1 for me - was now the norm rather than the Gleason score. My most recent PSA was 1.2, in fact down a tick from 1.4 at my last check in 2015. So I gather I'm in a pretty good place under the circumstances. I'm set to have an MRI in December after the biopsy sites heal, and then - oh goodie - a second confirmatory biopsy soon after that. In advance of those tests the docs are provisionally recommending Active Surveillance. Urologist #2 (a younger guy who seems to be on top of the latest stuff) expects a good result from the MRI and thinks it extremely unlikely that the cancer has gone anywhere outside the prostate. He mentioned optional genetic testing and said it would be a large chunk out of pocket. Dunno if Medicare, which I go on in a couple of weeks, will help with that or not but I'll certainly inquire if I decide to go that route. He did tell me that of all his patients who paid for it, none received bad news. As I recall he said that perhaps 10% of men would find out that their cancer is of the more aggressive type (or words to that effect, can't remember exactly). I'd love to get members' opinions as well as any suggestions for questions I should ask or other tests I might explore. I'm in my first week of gathering knowledge - have a couple of books on the subject, one recommended by the urologist called "Surviving Prostate Cancer" by Dr. Patrick Walsh. Also per his advice I've ordered pomegranate extract, Guanabana and Moringa. My dear friends at Amazon dot com should be showing up any minute with those. Thanks, guys. SC

Posts.Title: Hello from a new member

Posts.Content: Hello the group: so in reading some posts (I'm new) the issue of pain relief following surgery, etc. comes up now and then. During my 2009 head and neck cancer treatment I was eating Oxycodone like candy, and even added a Fentanyl patch for the last week of rads. I know these were lifesavers, but of course come with their own risks and unpleasantness, to say nothing of the possibility of dependence (luckily not for me but I know it happens). Perhaps some of you know about kratom. It's much in the news nowadays mainly because of the FDA and DEA's attempts to outlaw it, unfortunately. Kratom, which usually comes in powdered form, is the crushed leaf of a relative of the coffee tree that grows primarily in Indonesia (Kalimantan) and SE Asia. It's a natural analgesic that helps with pain, anxiety and a whole host of other issues. It is used extensively here in the USA, including as an aid to getting off opiods. I want to be clear (and speaking of clearing, I've done that with our moderator Chuck): kratom does not cure anything. It merely helps with those afore-mentioned issues and is an organic alternative to the stronger pharma products. You can look it up - there's a good wikipedia page. Anyone interested in more info please feel free to PM me. Thanks for listening. SC

Posts.Title: Pain relief

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Michael F Hi SC! You are on top this! Only those who have experienced H/N curative treatments can understand the associated pain and effects that you have been through. We can assure you that pain/discomfort following RP is both minimal and brief - in most cases. Before deciding that surgery is on the horizon, take time to: - Rule In or Out Active Surveillance - Seek expert 2nd opinions to make a highly informed determination as to which treatment option best addresses your specific pathology, overall health status & psyche - Ultimately you want to be treated by an expert MD who specializes in PCa If RP is your shared decision, be certain that your URO Surgeon is highly experienced (averaging 3-5 RPs per week). Robotic does offer advantages of less blood loss and no long incision. If deciding between Open vs Robotic RP, keep in mind that a highly skilled "Open" RP URO Surgeon is a better choice than an inexperienced "Robotic" URO Surgeon. Keep asking questions & seeking expert MD advice. Good luck getting all of the issues into clear focus! MF Thanks again, Michael. From everything I've heard (from the docs) and read (here and in Patrick Walsh's book) I'm a good candidate for AS. Scheduled for an MRI on 12/6 then another visit with the robotics Uro (he's done 400 of them and I hope I don't have need of his expertise for many years, if at all) and finally a confirmatory biopsy in the new year. So far so good!

Posts.Title: Update on my other condition...

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Another My surgery experience had discomfort, but very little pain requiring treatment. Standard over the counter pain relief was more than enough and I didn't need much of that. Eating oxycodone like candy is never a good idea. Hope your doing so didn't cause long term problems for you. I agree on the oxy-candy advice. However it was unfortunately necessary. In fact at the time I'd never heard of it, knew nothing of opioid abuse and only needed something to deal with the incredible, increasing pain of having my body radiated every day for 31 days from my mandibles to my clavicle- and for a good month afterward as I was still "cooking". Please understand, I'm not looking for sympathy when I type this: just stating facts. Right now it all seems like a kind of dream. (and no, no long term problems but I appreciate your concern!)

Posts.Content: Just got an email from my urologist. Here are the salient points: FINAL PATHOLOGIC DIAGNOSIS PROSTATE, RIGHT ANTERIOR, UroNAV CORE BIOPSY: 1. PROSTATIC ADENOCARCINOMA, GLEASON'S GRADE 3+3, SCORE 6, GRADE GROUP 1 2. THE TUMOR OCCUPIES APPROXIMATELY 10% OF ONE OUT OF 6 CORE BIOPSIES These cores were taken from the 15.5mm mass discovered in my initial MRI. In that one - the regular scattershot approach - 2 cores were found with positive volume: one (rt anterior) at 5%; one (lft anterior) at 15%. At the time the doctor told me I was a good candidate for AS. Now here's what he added to the new report: "We hit the MRI target which is also prostate cancer, grade 6. Given the MRI findings this should be treated." I'd been under the impression (mainly from reading the Walsh book) that Gleason 6 cancer, my low PSA (if that even applies at this point), age and the small volume of the cores, that I was in either the very low or low risk category and would therefore be a candidate for AS. I'd love it if anyone could shed some light on all this, because now I'm offcially confused. Thanks, guys. SC
